response.answer_text: The rate of technological development in the automobile industry is improving year by year. What was thought to be concept few years back are now a reality. Here are few examples: Flying Cars: Flying cars are finally about to enter production. Prototypes were being built and tested since the early years of twentieth century.  Electric Cars: The first practical production electric cars were built in 1884. But soon they were eclipsed by the efficiency of Internal Combustion engines . With the development of new battery technologies since 2008, performance of electric cars rapidly increased to compete with Gasoline cars. Soon, fossil fuel based cars will be considered obsolete. Autonomous Cars: We are familiar with fully autonomous cars from science fiction movies like i robot. Autonomous vehicles appeared as concepts and prototypes since 80s. The world started taking it serious when Tesla offered its autopilot system to its customers in 2014. At present, Tesla autopilot is not considered as fully autonomous but Elon Musk promises that this system will be more efficient and safe than human drivers in the near future.  Smart Cars: Every gadget is getting smarter everyday with the help of IOT(Internet of things) and Artificial Intelligence. In future, cars will get smarter and gets integrated with other technologies such as home automation.  Bio-metric Vehicle Access - We are not going to need a key in our pocket to access the car. Our fingerprint or eyeball will do the job. Head-Up-Displays - HUD had been used in military aircraft for many years. But now, the technology is getting cheaper that it will be available on car windshields in the near future.  These are just few examples of many interesting technology that are transforming the automotive industry.

Going through an article published in The Economic Times, Auto Technology I was astounded by some of the really fascinating innovations in coming future. There could be so many new innovations but let's talk about those only which we might experience in near future. So here are some of them. Pre-Collision Technology - Top carmakers such as Ford and Hyundai have developed a pre-collision assist and pedestrian detection technology. Besides helping the driver detect blind spots, this technology also alerts the driver when he/she is not paying attention on the road. And if the driver falls asleep and does not respond to the warning, then the system applies the brakes on its own. V2V Communications - In February, US National Highway Traffic Safety Administration announced that it will begin taking steps to enable vehicle-to-vehicle (V2V) communication technology for light vehicles. This technology would allow vehicles to "talk" to each other and ultimately avoid many crashes altogether by exchanging basic safety data, such as speed and position, ten times per second, to improve safety. Land Rover's Invisible Car - In April, Tata -owned JLR introduced a new technology to give drivers a digital vision of the terrain ahead by making the front of the car 'virtually' invisible. The technology — named Transparent Bonnet — enables a driver climbing a steep incline or manoeuvring in a confined space to see an augmented reality view capturing not only the terrain in front of the car but also the angle and position of the front wheels. Aumated Manual Transmission(AMT) - In the 2014 Delhi Auto Expo, where more than 70 vehicles were launched, one that pundits hailed as the most important was Maruti Suzuki's Celerio, the first affordable mass segment gearless hatchback. Celerio comes with AMT (automate manual transmission) sourced from Magneti Marelli, component arm of Fiat. AMT is an electro-hydraulic mechanism for automating manual transmission, which derives from Formula 1. Wait for the vehicles to be released in the market for consumers to buy, and then experience the ‘new’ technology. Each automotive company will have dedicated R&D teams working on technologies that are intended for commercial use 5 to 6 years from now, at any given time since the technology has to last the product life cycle. Off all the technology being researched for automotive purpose, probably only around 10% will become of widespread use and most often these technologies aren’t too mysterious. The electric vehicle existed well before vehicles with combustion engine came into place which was more than 100 years ago, but only recently has it become popular mainly due to Tesla.
